values.title: Save gazebo log file for each test in Jenkins

content.raw:
After pull request #894 is merged, console output will be suppressed for all tests that don't use ServerFixture. In order to debug test failures, it would be nice to have access to the gazebo log files in `~/.gazebo/test.log` for each test. Note that each test overwrites this file, so it will need to be saved in between tests.

Perhaps the test_ran check can also grab the `test.log` file?

@\_jrivero_
content.html:
After pull request #894 is merged, console output will be suppressed for all tests that don't use ServerFixture. In order to debug test failures, it would be nice to have access to the gazebo log files in ~/.gazebo/test.log for each test. Note that each test overwrites this file, so it will need to be saved in between tests.

Perhaps the test_ran check can also grab the test.log file?

@_jrivero_

values.title: gzsdf describe/doc commands ignore version number

content.raw:
The gzsdf command-line help for the `describe` and `doc` commands claim to accept a command-line argument for the sdf version ([gzsdf.cc:31](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/96fc32a7fef668545c8d36754110137fba5ece93/tools/gzsdf.cc?at=default#cl-31)), but the command-line argument is ignored and the latest version is always used. To confirm this for the `describe` command, observe identical shasum's: ~~~ $ gzsdf describe 1.0 | shasum e8187a31e27cb1a5562a81eb8af66f921e0d7e11 - $ gzsdf describe 1.2 | shasum e8187a31e27cb1a5562a81eb8af66f921e0d7e11 - $ gzsdf describe 1.3 | shasum e8187a31e27cb1a5562a81eb8af66f921e0d7e11 - $ gzsdf describe 1.4 | shasum e8187a31e27cb1a5562a81eb8af66f921e0d7e11 - ~~~ The shasum's are not identical for the `doc` command due to time stamps, but it can be confirmed that the latest version is being used by searching for `real_time_update_rate` or `max_step_size` in the resulting documentation, since these parameters were not added until version 1.4. ~~~ $ gzsdf doc 1.4 | grep real_time_update_rate <real_time_update_rate>
<real_time_update_rate>
$ gzsdf doc 1.3 | grep real_time_update_rate <real_time_update_rate>
<real_time_update_rate>
$ gzsdf doc 1.2 | grep real_time_update_rate <real_time_update_rate>
<real_time_update_rate>
$ gzsdf doc 1.0 | grep real_time_update_rate <real_time_update_rate>
<real_time_update_rate>
~~~ I discovered this while reviewing pull request #878. Also, the online documentation at gazebosim.org/sdf is version 1.4 for all listed versions.
content.html:
The gzsdf command-line help for the describe and doc commands claim to accept a command-line argument for the sdf version (gzsdf.cc:31), but the command-line argument is ignored and the latest version is always used.

To confirm this for the describe command, observe identical shasum's:

$ gzsdf describe 1.0 | shasum
e8187a31e27cb1a5562a81eb8af66f921e0d7e11  -
$ gzsdf describe 1.2 | shasum
e8187a31e27cb1a5562a81eb8af66f921e0d7e11  -
$ gzsdf describe 1.3 | shasum
e8187a31e27cb1a5562a81eb8af66f921e0d7e11  -
$ gzsdf describe 1.4 | shasum
e8187a31e27cb1a5562a81eb8af66f921e0d7e11  -

The shasum's are not identical for the doc command due to time stamps, but it can be confirmed that the latest version is being used by searching for real_time_update_rate or max_step_size in the resulting documentation, since these parameters were not added until version 1.4.

$ gzsdf doc 1.4 | grep real_time_update_rate
<a id='15' onclick='highlight(15);' href="#real_time_update_rate15">&ltreal_time_update_rate&gt</a><div style='padding-left:22px;'>
<a name="real_time_update_rate15">&ltreal_time_update_rate&gt</a><div style='padding-left:22px;'>
$ gzsdf doc 1.3 | grep real_time_update_rate
<a id='15' onclick='highlight(15);' href="#real_time_update_rate15">&ltreal_time_update_rate&gt</a><div style='padding-left:22px;'>
<a name="real_time_update_rate15">&ltreal_time_update_rate&gt</a><div style='padding-left:22px;'>
$ gzsdf doc 1.2 | grep real_time_update_rate
<a id='15' onclick='highlight(15);' href="#real_time_update_rate15">&ltreal_time_update_rate&gt</a><div style='padding-left:22px;'>
<a name="real_time_update_rate15">&ltreal_time_update_rate&gt</a><div style='padding-left:22px;'>
$ gzsdf doc 1.0 | grep real_time_update_rate
<a id='15' onclick='highlight(15);' href="#real_time_update_rate15">&ltreal_time_update_rate&gt</a><div style='padding-left:22px;'>
<a name="real_time_update_rate15">&ltreal_time_update_rate&gt</a><div style='padding-left:22px;'>

I discovered this while reviewing pull request #878.

Also, the online documentation at gazebosim.org/sdf is version 1.4 for all listed versions.

values.title: Find OGRE using cmake find_package rather than pkg-config

content.raw:
Currently we find packages related to OGRE [using pkg-config](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/96fc32a7fef668545c8d36754110137fba5ece93/cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake?at=default#cl-183). We should switch to using cmake `find_package` to improve cross-platform support.

For example, on Mac OSX we currently have a [patched formula for OGRE](https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/blob/master/ogre.rb) in the osrf/simulation homebrew tap. Some of the patches are needed to fix the pkg-config setup. In recent testing of ogre 1.9 on OSX, it appears that cmake `find_package` has much better cross-platform support than pkg-config for OGRE.
content.html:
Currently we find packages related to OGRE using pkg-config. We should switch to using cmake find_package to improve cross-platform support.

For example, on Mac OSX we currently have a patched formula for OGRE in the osrf/simulation homebrew tap. Some of the patches are needed to fix the pkg-config setup. In recent testing of ogre 1.9 on OSX, it appears that cmake find_package has much better cross-platform support than pkg-config for OGRE.

values.title: Scene::GetVisualCount()  return wrong value

content.html:
It seems that the number of Visuals returned from Scene::GetVisualCount() is less then the actual Visuals.

you can recreate this problem using the following code.

    unsigned int num_visual = m_scene->GetVisualCount();
    cout << "num of visual instance:" << num_visual << endl;
    unsigned int temp_count = 0;
    // go through every visual in rendering::Scene
    for( unsigned int i = 1; i < num_visual + 99; i++ ) // skip the first one
    {
        rendering::VisualPtr cur_visual = m_scene->GetVisual( i );

        if( cur_visual )
        {
            cout << "== " << i << " ==" << endl;
        }
        else
        {
            temp_count++;
        }
    }

NOTE in the for loop condition, i add 99 to num_visual.

The output will exceed number of Visuals returned by Scene::GetVisualCount().

OUTPUT:

...
== 1231 ==
== 1232 ==
== 1233 ==

num of visuals : 1229

values.title: Gazebo-2.1.0 fails to compile on ARM

content.raw:
Fedora ARM building machines are reporting [failures while building gazebo-2.1.0 on an ARM platform](http://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/taskinfo?taskID=6362362)

Thanks to @rmattes for the report and the debug, in his own words:

*
Basically, Qt typedefs "qreal" to double on every platform except for ARM.  On ARM it's a float, so you run into issues where people assume it's always a double, like in the templated implementations of std::min and std::max.
*
content.html:
Fedora ARM building machines are reporting failures while building gazebo-2.1.0 on an ARM platform

Thanks to @rmattes for the report and the debug, in his own words:

Basically, Qt typedefs "qreal" to double on every platform except for ARM. On ARM it's a float, so you run into issues where people assume it's always a double, like in the templated implementations of std::min and std::max.

values.title: ModelDatabase sometimes loads models with older sdf version

content.raw:
For models with multiple sdf files listed in the model.config ([sun](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/src/default/sun/model.config) for example), gazebo will sometimes load the oldest version of the model.

This occurs when the `SDF_VERSION` does not match any of the specified sdf versions in the `model.config` file. When this occurs, gazebo simply chooses the first one in the list.

Is this intended? I would expect it to choose the most recent version that it can support.

To reproduce the issue, simply remove the line giving the file name for the `1.4` version of the sun, and observe that gazebo loads the `1.2` version rather than `1.3`.
~~~
diff -r cec564005240 sun/model.config
--- a/sun/model.config	Mon Dec 02 11:34:20 2013 -0800
+++ b/sun/model.config	Thu Jan 16 16:54:57 2014 -0800
@@ -5,7 +5,6 @@
   <version>1.0</version>
   <sdf version="1.2">model-1_2.sdf</sdf>
   <sdf version="1.3">model-1_3.sdf</sdf>
-  <sdf version="1.4">model.sdf</sdf>
 
   <author>
     <name>Nate Koenig</name>
~~~
~~~
$ gazebo
…
Warning [parser.cc:340] Converting a deprecated source[/Users/scpeters/osrf/gazebo_models/sun/model-1_2.sdf].
Warning [Converter.cc:59]   Version[1.2] to Version[1.4]
  Please use the gzsdf tool to update your SDF files.
    $ gzsdf convert [sdf_file]
~~~
I thought this was a known issue, but I couldn't find an existing one that matched this. The code to change is in [ModelDatabase::GetModelFile](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/6f357235d464f26f5ffc61f90e17e67f788703f5/gazebo/common/ModelDatabase.cc?at=default#cl-623).
content.html:
For models with multiple sdf files listed in the model.config (sun for example), gazebo will sometimes load the oldest version of the model.

This occurs when the SDF_VERSION does not match any of the specified sdf versions in the model.config file. When this occurs, gazebo simply chooses the first one in the list.

Is this intended? I would expect it to choose the most recent version that it can support.

To reproduce the issue, simply remove the line giving the file name for the 1.4 version of the sun, and observe that gazebo loads the 1.2 version rather than 1.3.

diff -r cec564005240 sun/model.config
--- a/sun/model.config  Mon Dec 02 11:34:20 2013 -0800
+++ b/sun/model.config  Thu Jan 16 16:54:57 2014 -0800
@@ -5,7 +5,6 @@
   <version>1.0</version>
   <sdf version="1.2">model-1_2.sdf</sdf>
   <sdf version="1.3">model-1_3.sdf</sdf>
-  <sdf version="1.4">model.sdf</sdf>

   <author>
     <name>Nate Koenig</name>

$ gazebo
…
Warning [parser.cc:340] Converting a deprecated source[/Users/scpeters/osrf/gazebo_models/sun/model-1_2.sdf].
Warning [Converter.cc:59]   Version[1.2] to Version[1.4]
  Please use the gzsdf tool to update your SDF files.
    $ gzsdf convert [sdf_file]

I thought this was a known issue, but I couldn't find an existing one that matched this. The code to change is in ModelDatabase::GetModelFile.

values.title: Give parameters into included models in a SDF

content.raw:
Hi,
After walking around answers.gazebosim.org and google I couldn't find a way to pass parameters to an included model that modify a plugin.

I wanted to create a robot sdf including the platform and sensors, so I could reuse code.
At the end I copied-pasted the sensors sdf file into the robot's sdf.

This is an example of what i wanted to do:

robot.sdf

```
#!xml

  <model name="robot">
    <static>0</static>
    <!-- platform -->
    <include>
      <uri>model://platform</uri>
    </include>
    <!-- laser 1 -->
    <include>
      <uri>model://laser</uri>
      <param>value 1</param>
    </include>
    <!-- laser 2 -->
    <include>
      <uri>model://laser</uri>
      <param>value 2</param>
    </include>
  </model>
```
I hope there's a way to do it,

Thanks!
content.html:
Hi, After walking around answers.gazebosim.org and google I couldn't find a way to pass parameters to an included model that modify a plugin.

I wanted to create a robot sdf including the platform and sensors, so I could reuse code. At the end I copied-pasted the sensors sdf file into the robot's sdf.

This is an example of what i wanted to do:

robot.sdf

  <model name="robot">
    <static>0</static>
    <!-- platform -->
    <include>
      <uri>model://platform</uri>
    </include>
    <!-- laser 1 -->
    <include>
      <uri>model://laser</uri>
      <param>value 1</param>
    </include>
    <!-- laser 2 -->
    <include>
      <uri>model://laser</uri>
      <param>value 2</param>
    </include>
  </model>

I hope there's a way to do it,

Thanks!

values.title: Assertion error when unloading plugins

content.raw:
This happens when launching `gzserver` with a world that has a plugin, and pressing CTRL-C to kill the process. The following message is produced:


```
#!c++

Inconsistency detected by ld.so: dl-close.c: 759: _dl_close: Assertion `map->l_init_called' failed!
```

Note that it does not happen running the world with `gazebo`, and so far we can only produce this on one particular machine:

 - kernel - 3.2.0-48-generic

- libdlrestrictions1 - 0.14.2ubuntu5
content.html:
This happens when launching gzserver with a world that has a plugin, and pressing CTRL-C to kill the process. The following message is produced:

Inconsistency detected by ld.so: dl-close.c: 759: _dl_close: Assertion `map->l_init_called' failed!

Note that it does not happen running the world with gazebo, and so far we can only produce this on one particular machine:

  • kernel - 3.2.0-48-generic

  • libdlrestrictions1 - 0.14.2ubuntu5

values.title: SimbodyLink::SetLinearVel not implemented

content.raw:
[SimbodyLink::SetLinearVel](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/78fdd811f1ad6d82c17c22592e77b0ef51e1f084/gazebo/physics/simbody/SimbodyLink.cc?at=default#cl-283) is not yet implemented. ~~This is needed in the [SpawnJointRotational test](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/78fdd811f1ad6d82c17c22592e77b0ef51e1f084/gazebo/physics/Joint_TEST.cc?at=default#cl-530)~~.

EDIT: It's called from that test, but it doesn't seem to be needed since simbody already passed that test with the revolute joint. We should add an explicit test for `Link::SetLinearVel`.
content.html:
SimbodyLink::SetLinearVel is not yet implemented. This is needed in the SpawnJointRotational test.

EDIT: It's called from that test, but it doesn't seem to be needed since simbody already passed that test with the revolute joint. We should add an explicit test for Link::SetLinearVel.

values.title: libgazebo_ros_api_plugin.so: undefined symbol on Ubuntu 12.04 since 2014/01/21

content.raw:
Since apt-get (dist-)upgrade yesterday, rosrun gazebo_ros gazebo fails with
```
symbol lookup error: /opt/ros/hydro/lib/libgazebo_ros_api_plugin.so: undefined symbol: _ZN3ros7console5printEPNS0_10FilterBaseEPN7log4cxx6LoggerENS0_6levels5LevelEPKciS9_S9_z
```

should be stemming from librosconsole.so
```
(grep -r 'ros.*console.*print.*FilterBase.*log.*Logger.*levels.*LevelEPK' /opt/ros/hydro/lib/libros*
Binary file /opt/ros/hydro/lib/librosconsole.so matches)
```

Relevant parts from dpkg -l:
```
gazebo-current                                2.2.1-1~precise
ros-hydro-gazebo-*-current             2.4.1-1precise
ros-hydro-rosconsole                       1.9.53-0precise-20140115-0235-+0000
```

Perhaps ros-hydro-gazebo*-current needs to be recompiled against current ros-hydro-rosconsole?
content.html:

ros-hydro-gazebo-*-current             2.4.1-1precise
ros-hydro-rosconsole                       1.9.53-0precise-20140115-0235-+0000

Perhaps ros-hydro-gazebo*-current needs to be recompiled against current ros-hydro-rosconsole?

values.title: Camera visualization causes GLWidget to freeze on OSX

content.raw:
Inserting a model that has a camera with the `<visualize>` tag set to true causes the rendering of the GLWidget to freeze on OSX. These models include the [camera](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/src/391a3377cae498583939e788b8971a11d340dd73/camera/model.sdf?at=default) and [pr2](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/src/391a3377cae498583939e788b8971a11d340dd73/pr2/model.sdf?at=default) in the model database.

After inserting one of these models, the 3D rendering freezes, though the time continues to display at the bottom of the screen, and the topic viewers work as well (even the camera image topic viewers).
content.html:
Inserting a model that has a camera with the <visualize> tag set to true causes the rendering of the GLWidget to freeze on OSX. These models include the camera and pr2 in the model database.

After inserting one of these models, the 3D rendering freezes, though the time continues to display at the bottom of the screen, and the topic viewers work as well (even the camera image topic viewers).

values.title: Error opening log file gzserver.log

content.raw:
If for some reason (older gazebo) `/home/user/.gazebo/gzserver.log` is a directory, when trying to run gazebo from default branch one encounters the following error:

~~~
$ gazebo
Error opening log file: "/home/hsu/.gazebo/gzserver.log"
~~~

If for some reason (older gazebo) /home/user/.gazebo/gzserver.log is a directory, when trying to run gazebo from default branch one encounters the following error:

values.title: Compiling Gazebo 3.0 without Player support

content.raw:
When `libplayer*` is installed on my debian system, I am unable to compile Gazebo 3.0 (default branch) and instead get:

```
/home/dave/ros/ws_gazebo/gazebo/interfaces/player/player.h:22:38: fatal error: libplayercore/playercore.h: No such file or directory
```

But I have libplayercore3.0-dev installed. There does not appear to be a -I/usr/include/player3.0 when I compile. I do have the file:

```
/usr/include/player-3.0/libplayercore/playercore.h
```
The compile flags are:
```
cd /home/dave/ros/ws_gazebo/gazebo/build/gazebo/gui && /usr/bin/c++   -Dgazebo_gui_EXPORTS -DLIBBULLET_VERSION=0.0 -DQT_GUI_LIB -DQT_CORE_LIB -DQT_NO_DEBUG -g -O2 -mssse3 -msse3 -mfpmath=sse -msse -msse2  -Wall -Wextra -Wno-long-long
```

From [Gazebo Answers](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/5269/drcsim-precise-hydro/?comment=5279#comment-5279)

I was able to compile by uninstalling libplayer*
content.html:
When libplayer* is installed on my debian system, I am unable to compile Gazebo 3.0 (default branch) and instead get:

/home/dave/ros/ws_gazebo/gazebo/interfaces/player/player.h:22:38: fatal error: libplayercore/playercore.h: No such file or directory

But I have libplayercore3.0-dev installed. There does not appear to be a -I/usr/include/player3.0 when I compile. I do have the file:

/usr/include/player-3.0/libplayercore/playercore.h

values.title: protobuf ParseFromString function return value not checked

content.html:
While debugging #821 (transport race conditions), I noticed that the protobuf ParseFromString function is used frequently without checking its return value (bool) to see if it was successful.

In my overnight testing, I added a check to Master.cc:169, since I had seen some failures in this portion of the code:

diff -r 56ef8eb1faaa gazebo/Master.cc
--- a/gazebo/Master.cc  Tue Dec 17 19:02:34 2013 +0000
+++ b/gazebo/Master.cc  Fri Dec 20 13:47:13 2013 -0800
@@ -166,7 +166,13 @@
   {
     boost::recursive_mutex::scoped_lock lock(this->connectionMutex);
     msgs::Publish pub;
-    pub.ParseFromString(packet.serialized_data());
+    if (!pub.ParseFromString(packet.serialized_data()))
+    {
+      gzerr << "ParseFromString failed:"
+            << " packet.type() " << packet.type()
+            << " packet.serialized_data() " << packet.serialized_data()
+            << std::endl;
+    }

     Connection_M::iterator iter2;
     for (iter2 = this->connections.begin();

I've omitted the serialized data below since it is binary data and didn't print well, but the failure of this function was a precursor to the Can't serialize message exception that is the hallmark of #821.

[Err] [Master.cc:171] ParseFromString failed: packet.type() advertise packet.serialized_data()
...
[Err] [Exception.cc:52] EXCEPTION: Can't serialize message of type[gazebo.msgs.Publish] because it is missing required fields

So I suggest always checking the return value of ParseFromString, which may help with #821.

values.title: Failing tests with sensor noise since pull request #923

content.raw:
There's some [Jenkins tests failing](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-default-devel-quantal-amd64-gpu-nvidia/482/testReport/) due to an assertion:
~~~
105: [ RUN      ] NoiseTest.ApplyGaussian
105: ***** Internal Program Error - assertion (noise->GetNoiseType() == Noise::GAUSSIAN || noise->GetNoiseType() == Noise::GAUSSIAN_QUANTIZED) failed in static gazebo::sensors::NoisePtr gazebo::sensors::NoiseFactory::NewNoiseModel(sdf::ElementPtr, const string&):
105: /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo-default-devel-quantal-amd64-gpu-nvidia/gazebo/gazebo/sensors/Noise.cc(50): Noise type should be 'gaussian' or 'gaussian_quantized'
105/128 Test #105: UNIT_Noise_TEST ........................***Exception: Other  2.55 sec
~~~

I followed a backtrace to instances of the GaussianNoiseModel class, which isn't setting its `Noise::type` value.

I proposed a fix in pull request #923, but major refactoring of the Sensor::Noise class was requested, so I declined that pull request and stopped working on it.

values.title: Duplicate parameter definitions

content.raw:
I've been working on improving the friction parameters, and I've noticed that we currently define physics parameters in sdformat, protobuf messages, and the gazebo physics classes. Changing the parameter definitions in protobuf or the physics classes often breaks API/ABI. Lots of duplication to keep in sync.

This is something to think about as we consider changes to the physics API.

Changing the parameter definitions in protobuf or the physics classes often breaks API/ABI. Lots of duplication to keep in sync.

This is something to think about as we consider changes to the physics API.

values.title: Use boost temporary folders instead of /tmp

content.raw:
We have lots of hard-coded references to /tmp in gazebo when we need a temporary folder. This can cause problems with multi-user systems (see #631) and also portability issues across operating systems (Windows).

There is a function in pull request #938 that creates temporary folders. This should be used to replace all uses of `/tmp` in the gazebo source code.
content.html:
We have lots of hard-coded references to /tmp in gazebo when we need a temporary folder. This can cause problems with multi-user systems (see #631) and also portability issues across operating systems (Windows).

There is a function in pull request #938 that creates temporary folders. This should be used to replace all uses of /tmp in the gazebo source code.

values.title: Simbody link gravity mode inefficient

content.raw:
Simbody currently polls the gravity mode for each link, as seen in this [pull-request](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/866/patches-to-get-drcsim-working-with-simbody/diff#Lgazebo/physics/simbody/SimbodyLink.ccT96).

It would be better to use an event based system, since polling across every link is inefficient.
content.html:
Simbody currently polls the gravity mode for each link, as seen in this pull-request.

It would be better to use an event based system, since polling across every link is inefficient.

values.title: Build osx gazebo app that can be double-clicked

values.title: gzlog echo -r -s sim doesn't print correct timestamps

content.raw:
The problem is trying to print the data in raw xml-free mode.

For example, here is a log file with two timestamps that can be seen properly in xml:
~~~
$ gzlog echo test/data/pr2_state.log --filter pr2/base_footprint.pose.x
...
<chunk encoding='txt'><![CDATA[
<sdf version='1.4'>
<state world_name='default'>
<sim_time>0 21343973</sim_time>
<real_time>0 1000000</real_time>
<wall_time>1360301758 939690376</wall_time>
<model name='pr2'>
<link name='base_footprint'>
0.000000 
</link>
</model>
</sdf></state>
]]></chunk>
<chunk encoding='txt'><![CDATA[
<sdf version='1.4'>
<state world_name='default'>
<sim_time>0 28958235</sim_time>
<real_time>0 2000000</real_time>
<wall_time>1360301758 947304437</wall_time>
<model name='pr2'>
<link name='base_footprint'>
0.000000 
</link>
</model>
</sdf></state>
]]></chunk>

~~~

Printing in "raw" mode gives zeros for sim and real:
~~~
$ gzlog echo pr2_state.log --filter pr2/base_footprint.pose.x -r -s sim
0 0.000000 
0 0.000000 
$ gzlog echo pr2_state.log --filter pr2/base_footprint.pose.x -r -s real
0 0.000000 
0 0.000000 
~~~
The wall clock is nonzero, but with insufficient precision:
~~~
1.39164e+09 0.000000 
1.39164e+09 0.000000
~~~

</sdf></state>
]]></chunk>

Printing in "raw" mode gives zeros for sim and real:

values.title: collide_without_contact only supported by ODE

The [surface_properties](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/79296f5598905af4ca08a2042d983761c447702a/test/integration/surface_properties.cc?at=default#cl-171) test should be expanded when other physics engines support it.
content.html: The collide_without_contact tag used by the MudPlugin and SonarSensor is only supported by ODE. The surface_properties test should be expanded when other physics engines support it.

values.title: Convert opende libraries to be static

content.raw:
This issue comes from discussion on pull request #909

As of now, we were generating 4 shared libraries which are not really being used anywhere more than in gazebo_physics_ode. Since they are a fork of the official ode libraries I would prefer no to re-distribute them (libs and headers) if possible.

The approach would be to change them to be static and statically linked them into gazebo_physics_ode and not to install all related headers files.  After this first step, we will be able to define as ```GAZEBO_VISIBLE``` the functions on ```gazebo/physics/ode``` and all symbols from our ode fork will keep not exported, which I believe is a good thing to do. 

@nkoenig commented about the need of access ODE core features and be able to get a pointer to the underlying physics engine.
content.html:
This issue comes from discussion on pull request #909

As of now, we were generating 4 shared libraries which are not really being used anywhere more than in gazebo_physics_ode. Since they are a fork of the official ode libraries I would prefer no to re-distribute them (libs and headers) if possible.

The approach would be to change them to be static and statically linked them into gazebo_physics_ode and not to install all related headers files. After this first step, we will be able to define as GAZEBO_VISIBLE the functions on gazebo/physics/ode and all symbols from our ode fork will keep not exported, which I believe is a good thing to do.

@nkoenig commented about the need of access ODE core features and be able to get a pointer to the underlying physics engine.

values.title: Plugins in test/plugins not found by SpringDamperTest

content.raw:
Console output from [Jenkins test failure](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-quantal-amd64-gpu-nvidia/lastCompletedBuild/testReport/%28root%29/PhysicsEngines_JointTest/SpringDamperTest_0/):
~~~
153: [Err] [Plugin.hh:152] Failed to load plugin libSpringTestPlugin.so:
libSpringTestPlugin.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
~~~
This plugin used to be in `plugins`, but it got moved to `test/plugins` in pull request #874. I tested that on my local machine, which had an old copy of that plugin installed, but with clean installs, it not able to be found.

The pull request attempted to solve the problem by assuming the build folder location (bad idea actually) and adding `build/test/plugins` to the gazebo system paths, which actually won't work, since [Plugin.hh calls SystemPaths::GetPluginPaths()](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/c2be69776af1f88bf11d69680600b2b4018e6161/gazebo/common/Plugin.hh?at=default#cl-118), which itself only checks the [GAZEBO_PLUGIN_PATH environment variable](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/c2be69776af1f88bf11d69680600b2b4018e6161/gazebo/common/SystemPaths.cc?at=default#cl-199).

So to fix this we should use the actual build folder location `CMAKE_BINARY_DIR` and then update the environment variable with this value? Or is there a better way?
content.html:
Console output from Jenkins test failure:

153: [Err] [Plugin.hh:152] Failed to load plugin libSpringTestPlugin.so:
libSpringTestPlugin.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory

This plugin used to be in plugins, but it got moved to test/plugins in pull request #874. I tested that on my local machine, which had an old copy of that plugin installed, but with clean installs, it not able to be found.

The pull request attempted to solve the problem by assuming the build folder location (bad idea actually) and adding build/test/plugins to the gazebo system paths, which actually won't work, since Plugin.hh calls SystemPaths::GetPluginPaths(), which itself only checks the GAZEBO_PLUGIN_PATH environment variable.

So to fix this we should use the actual build folder location CMAKE_BINARY_DIR and then update the environment variable with this value? Or is there a better way?

values.title: Consider exporting dynamics data in HDF5 interface

content.raw:
There is a proposal from researchers at RPI to use the [HDF5 data format](http://www.hdfgroup.org/HDF5/Tutor/fileorg.html) in order to [log dynamic simulation states](http://www.cs.rpi.edu/twiki/view/RoboticsWeb/Hdf5). This may be an opportunity to improve the performance of the Gazebo logging system.

HDF5 stands for Hierarchical Data Format (like a binary XML?).

References:

* [Technical paper describing logging format for dynamics](http://www.cs.rpi.edu/twiki/pub/RoboticsWeb/LabPublications/Standard_interface.pdf)
* [Sample hdf5 dynamics logs](http://code.google.com/p/rpi-matlab-simulator/source/browse/solver_work/h5data/)
* [Paper discussing XML vs. binary formats](http://www.hdfgroup.org/projects/nara/XML_and_Binary.pdf)
* [HDF5 command-line tools](http://www.hdfgroup.org/training/HDFtraining/UsersGuide/Utils.fm.html)
content.html:
There is a proposal from researchers at RPI to use the HDF5 data format in order to log dynamic simulation states. This may be an opportunity to improve the performance of the Gazebo logging system.

HDF5 stands for Hierarchical Data Format (like a binary XML?).

References:

  • Technical paper describing logging format for dynamics
  • Sample hdf5 dynamics logs
  • Paper discussing XML vs. binary formats
  • HDF5 command-line tools

values.title: Fix Clang warnings in gazebo

content.raw:
Latest compilation with Clang brings the nice number of [73 warnings](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew_bcn-amd64/8/warnings3Result/new/?).

There are a [good bunch of them](
http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew_bcn-amd64/8/warnings3Result/NORMAL/package.1334695212/file.-1070118982/source.55676/#38) that come from -Woverloaded-virtual, so probably we will need to specify the use of parent class method.
content.html:
Latest compilation with Clang brings the nice number of 73 warnings.

There are a good bunch of them that come from -Woverloaded-virtual, so probably we will need to specify the use of parent class method.

values.title: Custom friction directions not implemented in bullet

content.raw: We haven't implemented the use of custom friction directions (see fdir1 parameter in ODE and issue #630).
content.html: We haven't implemented the use of custom friction directions (see fdir1 parameter in ODE and issue #630).

values.title: Calling World::Reset causes a deadlock during shutdown on osx

content.raw:
Several regression tests timeout on OSX, and I have traced it to a deadlock in SensorContainer::RunLoop when World::Reset has been called.

There is a test in 833ad60 that passes on Ubuntu and times out on osx.
content.html:
Several regression tests timeout on OSX, and I have traced it to a deadlock in SensorContainer::RunLoop when World::Reset has been called.

There is a test in 833ad60 that passes on Ubuntu and times out on osx.

values.title: Make starting simulation time a parameter

content.raw: Allow user to adjust startup simulation time easily (currently 0 or 1ms in drcsim).  This could be used to spoof wall time if desired. See [this issue](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/issue/391).
content.html: Allow user to adjust startup simulation time easily (currently 0 or 1ms in drcsim). This could be used to spoof wall time if desired. See this issue.

content.raw: We haven't implemented the use of custom friction directions (see fdir1 parameter in ODE and issue #630).

values.title: Gazebo issues on Sourceforge playerstage issue tracker

content.raw: There are still a bunch of issues open for Gazebo on the Player issue tracker on Sourceforge from back when Gazebo was hosted there.  I'm trying to do some bug triage and make sure there are no outstanding issues before releasing Player 3.1, and I'm wondering what to do with the bugs that are still around for Gazebo.  Should I just mass close them all with a note to re-open on this issue tracker?  Do you guys want to go through them yourselves and make sure there's nothing still relevant there?
content.html: There are still a bunch of issues open for Gazebo on the Player issue tracker on Sourceforge from back when Gazebo was hosted there. I'm trying to do some bug triage and make sure there are no outstanding issues before releasing Player 3.1, and I'm wondering what to do with the bugs that are still around for Gazebo. Should I just mass close them all with a note to re-open on this issue tracker? Do you guys want to go through them yourselves and make sure there's nothing still relevant there?

values.title: Consider c++11 support

content.raw:
The simbody developers have expressed some interest in `c++11` features (starting with [this pull request](https://github.com/simbody/simbody/pull/123) that simply fixes some build issues and adds a continuous integration build option for `c++11`.

If simbody moves to require `c++11` support, it is my understanding that this will complicate gazebo's linking with other dependencies.
content.html:
The simbody developers have expressed some interest in c++11 features (starting with this pull request that simply fixes some build issues and adds a continuous integration build option for c++11.

If simbody moves to require c++11 support, it is my understanding that this will complicate gazebo's linking with other dependencies.

values.title: UTM support for GpsSensor (patch from player)

content.raw: There is a long-standing [patch on player's sourceforge to add a GPS sensor model](https://sourceforge.net/p/playerstage/patches/636) to gazebo (which I hadn't seen before submitting pull request #647). It includes UTM support and a player interface.
content.html: There is a long-standing patch on player's sourceforge to add a GPS sensor model to gazebo (which I hadn't seen before submitting pull request #647). It includes UTM support and a player interface.

content.raw: There was a patch posted to the [player sourceforge](https://sourceforge.net/p/playerstage/patches/637/) that improves Player IMU support with gazebo.

values.title: Update GearBox Joint Definition

content.raw:
Current model definition for gearbox joint is not flexible enough.

We should switch from needing parent link, child link, reference link, axis1 and axis2 to specifying 2 single dof revolute/prismatic joints.

Inspired by trying to model pr2 like 4-joint parallel gripper.
content.html:
Current model definition for gearbox joint is not flexible enough.

We should switch from needing parent link, child link, reference link, axis1 and axis2 to specifying 2 single dof revolute/prismatic joints.

Inspired by trying to model pr2 like 4-joint parallel gripper.

values.title: Occasional UNIT_GpsSensor_TEST failure

content.raw:
[Occasional UNIT_GpsSensor_TEST failure in Jenkins](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-quantal-amd64-gpu-nvidia/535/testReport/junit/(root)/UNIT_GpsSensor_TEST/test_ran/) (the following build did not fail). It has the following console error:
~~~
103: [==========] Running 1 test from 1 test case.
103: [----------] Global test environment set-up.
103: [----------] 1 test from GpsSensor_TEST
103: [ RUN      ] GpsSensor_TEST.CreateGps
103: UNIT_GpsSensor_TEST: /usr/include/boost/smart_ptr/shared_ptr.hpp:424: T* boost::shared_ptr<T>::operator->() const [with T = gazebo::sensors::Noise]: Assertion `px != 0' failed.
103: [Msg] Waiting for master.
103: [Msg] Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
103: [Msg] Publicized address: 192.168.1.196
103: [Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:144] ServerFixture load in 1.1 seconds, timeout after 600 seconds
103: [Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:95] ServerFixture::Unload
103: 
103/130 Test #103: UNIT_GpsSensor_TEST ....................***Exception: Other 10.94 sec
~~~

It happens very early in the test. A backtrace on my mac (where it fails very consistently) implicates the following line in [GpsSensor::UpdateImpl](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/c3f5afdbd905d03a326d5d4fb762421edc0a15aa/gazebo/sensors/GpsSensor.cc#cl-142):
~~~
-> 142 	      gpsVelocity.x = this->horizontalVelocityNoise->Apply(gpsVelocity.x);
~~~

The noise data structures get allocated in `GpsSensor::Load` as of pull request #936, so I'm guessing that the Sensor update loops are being started before everything has loaded properly.
content.html:
Occasional UNIT_GpsSensor_TEST failure in Jenkins (the following build did not fail). It has the following console error:

103: [==========] Running 1 test from 1 test case.
103: [----------] Global test environment set-up.
103: [----------] 1 test from GpsSensor_TEST
103: [ RUN      ] GpsSensor_TEST.CreateGps
103: UNIT_GpsSensor_TEST: /usr/include/boost/smart_ptr/shared_ptr.hpp:424: T* boost::shared_ptr<T>::operator->() const [with T = gazebo::sensors::Noise]: Assertion `px != 0' failed.
103: [Msg] Waiting for master.
103: [Msg] Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
103: [Msg] Publicized address: 192.168.1.196
103: [Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:144] ServerFixture load in 1.1 seconds, timeout after 600 seconds
103: [Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:95] ServerFixture::Unload
103: 
103/130 Test #103: UNIT_GpsSensor_TEST ....................***Exception: Other 10.94 sec

It happens very early in the test. A backtrace on my mac (where it fails very consistently) implicates the following line in GpsSensor::UpdateImpl:

-> 142        gpsVelocity.x = this->horizontalVelocityNoise->Apply(gpsVelocity.x);

The noise data structures get allocated in GpsSensor::Load as of pull request #936, so I'm guessing that the Sensor update loops are being started before everything has loaded properly.

values.title: virtual methods are hidden

content.html:
Migrated from a gazebo_ros_pkgs issue (note that they're using 1.9)

values.title: Playing Mario AI in gazebo

content.raw:
Hi folks,
I wanna play Mario AI game in Gazebo. On the Internet, i didn't find any usefull information to do that. But in my opinion the following steps are nessesary:

1. Import a real 3D environment in gazebo via "reconstruction of slam-data"
2. calculating all possible paths of the robot from actual location to goal
3. execute this goal

This idea is similar to what Emo Todorov has done, see his videos on his Website (moving a robot from current position to a home position).
content.html:
Hi folks, I wanna play Mario AI game in Gazebo. On the Internet, i didn't find any usefull information to do that. But in my opinion the following steps are nessesary:

  1. Import a real 3D environment in gazebo via "reconstruction of slam-data"
  2. calculating all possible paths of the robot from actual location to goal
  3. execute this goal

This idea is similar to what Emo Todorov has done, see his videos on his Website (moving a robot from current position to a home position).

values.title: BulletHingeJoint::GetAngle returns wrapped angle

content.raw: It's an upstream issue with btHingeConstraint::getHingeAngle (see [bullet ticket](https://github.com/erwincoumans/bullet3/issues/42) that I just filed). We apparently patched our copy of ODE to return unwrapped angles. We should probably try to push that upstream (among other things).

values.title: System plugin loading issue since gazebo-current 2.2.2-1~precise

content.html:
Since I upgraded Gazebo today, my System Plugins do not work anymore:

gzclient: /usr/include/boost/smart_ptr/shared_ptr.hpp:418: T* boost::shared_ptr<T>::operator->() const [with T = gazebo::rendering::Scene]: Assertion `px != 0' failed.

Stemming from:

  void
  GazeboMISGuiPlugin::Init()
  {
    std::cout << "------------------- GazeboMISGuiPlugin -------------------" << std::endl;
    rendering::ScenePtr scene = rendering::RenderEngine::Instance()->GetScene();
    Ogre::SceneManager* sceneManager = scene->GetManager();
    // ...
  }

Because GetScene() returns a NULL Pointer.

A similar issues exists for another System Plugin:

Error [PhysicsIface.cc:61] no worlds
Error [PhysicsIface.cc:75] Unable to find world by name in physics::get_world[]
Exception [PhysicsIface.cc:77] Unable to find world by name in physics::get_world(world_name)

coming from:

  void
  GazeboMISServerPlugin::Init()
  {
    std::cout << "------------------- GazeboMISServerPlugin -------------------" << std::endl;
    physics::WorldPtr world = physics::get_world();
    // ...
  }

Both plugins inherit from gazebo::SystemPlugin and are registered through GZ_REGISTER_SYSTEM_PLUGIN().

Both plugins work fine with previous package gazebo-current 2.2.1-1~precise.

My model plugins still work.

values.title: JointController does not handle correctly messages setting integral lower limit and command limits

content.raw:
Apparently the JointController class (in method OnJointCmd) does not handle correctly messages that are setting the integral lower limit or the command limits, both for position and velocity PID. 

Trying to set the integral lower limit result in setting the integral upper limit instead, while command limits messages are just ignored. 

A possible fix could be: https://bitbucket.org/traversaro/gazebo/commits/af9880d73b172b1def55a33e01fc48a3c8cecdcd
content.html:
Apparently the JointController class (in method OnJointCmd) does not handle correctly messages that are setting the integral lower limit or the command limits, both for position and velocity PID.

Trying to set the integral lower limit result in setting the integral upper limit instead, while command limits messages are just ignored.

A possible fix could be: https://bitbucket.org/traversaro/gazebo/commits/af9880d73b172b1def55a33e01fc48a3c8cecdcd

values.title: Debian packages for Gazebo 3.0 and ROS gazebo packages

content.raw:
Some groups want to install recent version of Gazebo (hopefully Gazebo 3.0) and ROS together from debian packages to use multiple physics engines feature. However, according to [wiki](http://gazebosim.org/wiki/Install/Gazebo_and_ROS), ROS currently works with Gazebo 1.9.x. In order to use recent version of Gazebo and ROS together, the user should build them from source.

When it will be possible to use recent version of Gazebo (Gazebo 3.0) and ROS from debian packages?

values.title: Add bullet solver parameters to msgs::physics
Better documentation needed for Joint::GetAngle()

content.raw:
So, `physics::Joint::GetAngle()` returns different quantities for different types of joints, and if one burrowed down into the documentation from the respective libraries, one would arrive at the following conclusions:

* revolute: The joint angle in the range -pi to pi
* gearbox: The joint angle in the range -pi to pi
* revolute2: The joint angle in the range -pi to pi
* prismatic: The joint's linear position
* ball: (not implemented) (returns Zero)
* universal: One of the joint's angles in the range -pi to pi
* piston: ???

But Gazebo patches these libraries to handle unwrapped angles in some cases. Where is the best place to document this behavior, in each joint class's implementation? If it goes there then it might not be visible to someone trying to understand the API. Should it just go in the Joint base class?
content.html:
So, physics::Joint::GetAngle() returns different quantities for different types of joints, and if one burrowed down into the documentation from the respective libraries, one would arrive at the following conclusions:

  • revolute: The joint angle in the range -pi to pi
  • gearbox: The joint angle in the range -pi to pi
  • revolute2: The joint angle in the range -pi to pi
  • prismatic: The joint's linear position
  • ball: (not implemented) (returns Zero)
  • universal: One of the joint's angles in the range -pi to pi
  • piston: ???

But Gazebo patches these libraries to handle unwrapped angles in some cases. Where is the best place to document this behavior, in each joint class's implementation? If it goes there then it might not be visible to someone trying to understand the API. Should it just go in the Joint base class?

values.title: Dynamically created joints act weird after version 1.8.0

content.raw:
Hi,

I had this issue before ( [issue1](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/3117/problems-creating-multiple-joints-dynamically/) , [issue2](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/5075/after-version-180-currently-210-dynamically/) ), however I didn't have the time until now to look into it in more detail.

In the older version >1.8.0 I used to spawn objects in the world and then connect them via dynamically created joints, however in later versions they act unnatural. I spawn the objects either from a plugin where I create an sdf from string and then insert it via `World::InsertModelSDF(const sdf::SDF &_sdf)` , I also tested it by including them from the .world file as a model.

I simplified the creation of the dynamic joints, took out all the physics parameters, and tried it in two ways, as a fixed joint and and a movable one (changing high and low stop).


```
#!c++
void Plugin::CreateDynamicJoint(physics::LinkPtr _center_link, physics::LinkPtr _ext_link)
{
	physics::JointPtr joint;

	joint = this->world->GetPhysicsEngine()->CreateJoint("revolute", this->myModel);

        // tried both versions by switching parent and child
	joint->Load(_center_link, _ext_link, math::Pose());
	joint->Attach(_center_link, _ext_link);

	joint->SetAxis(0, math::Vector3(0.0, 0.0, 1.0));

	joint->SetHighStop(0, 0);
	joint->SetLowStop(0, -0);
}
```

Here are some videos with how the models act after the joints are created ( I added some hardcoded visuals to it as well since dynamically created joints don't support visuals, see [Issue #1077](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue/1077/visualizing-dynamically-created-joints) , where, the green marked boxes are the `_ext_links`, and the blue marked box is the `_center_link`).

Videos with static joints ( high/low stop = 0 ):

[5 links](https://vimeo.com/88245296)

[7 links](https://vimeo.com/88245298)

[17 links](https://vimeo.com/88245300)

[35 links](https://vimeo.com/88245302)

[225 links](https://vimeo.com/88245303)


Videos with movable joints ( high/low stop = ~ +/- 0.3 ):

[5 moving links](https://vimeo.com/88245380)

[7 moving links](https://vimeo.com/88245377)

[14 moving links](https://vimeo.com/88245379)

[35 moving links](https://vimeo.com/88245378)

In the videos the hand touches the boxes first, then it creates a fixed joint with it to lift it up, sometimes they explode only when touching, other times when moving or dropping them.

During the tests I switched between child and parent links, meaning in one case `_ext_links` were the children, all connecting to the `_center_link` parent, and vice versa when all `_ext_links` were parents, and the only child, `_center_link`, was connecting to them.

Which brings up another question, the only difference between child and parent links is that the pose and axis when creating them is relative to the child, but it has nothing to do with the idea that a child link should have only one parent, so it should work both ways?

Here I have a video when multiple joints are already created in an SDF file, and this works without any problem.

[sdf joints](https://vimeo.com/88258797)

In the video when visualizing the joint you can only notice one, since they are all in one position. However after changing the parent with children, all the joints were visible on the external spheres, and it still worked.

I couldn't see the difference between creating the joints from sdf or dynamically, one calls [void Joint::Load(LinkPtr _parent, LinkPtr _child, const math::Pose &_pose)](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/bb512e8b7dcc77016370f47520b3183fdb9e27cf/gazebo/physics/Joint.cc?at=default#cl-94) and the other [void Joint::Load(sdf::ElementPtr _sdf)](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/bb512e8b7dcc77016370f47520b3183fdb9e27cf/gazebo/physics/Joint.cc?at=default#cl-120) which both then call with the given pose [void Joint::LoadImpl(const math::Pose &_pose)](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/bb512e8b7dcc77016370f47520b3183fdb9e27cf/gazebo/physics/Joint.cc?at=default#cl-209)

Am I doing something wrong, or this is just some kind of weird bug?

I will try now to create an sdf string dynamically regarding the positions of the links, add the joints there, delete the model and then spawn it from the sdf string, see how that behaves, I will keep you posted when that is finished.

==========================UPDATE!!!==================================

So it seems the problem is not with loading an SDF or not, I created a plugin which deletes the model, and creates a new one in SDF string form, with joints between the links, here are two videos with it (when the boxes turn green/blue the model has been deleted and re-spawned as SDF with joints) :

[center_parent](https://vimeo.com/88350985)

[center_child](https://vimeo.com/88350986)

As a next step I outputed the SDF string into a file and loaded it from the world:

[load from world](https://vimeo.com/88352832)

So it's obvious it has nothing to do with the way the joints are loaded, I am definitely doing something wrong, but I cannot figure it out what, maybe the joint axis counts, but that wouldn't be the case for fixed joints, plus the code worked for versions before 1.8.0.

Here are the sdf files of the working model (the pancake spheres), and the one that crashes (boxes).

[working_model](http://pastebin.com/3Twgb1SK)

[NOT_working](http://pastebin.com/8BsuKH8y)

==========================UPDATE!!!==================================

After some more testing and comparing I noticed that this happens because of the axis vector, it doesn't like all values, but this shouldn't really influence it in case it's a fixed joint. 

And if I put the value 0 0 1 it should rotate around the Z axis, I don't see why this should lead to such unstable situations.

==========================UPDATE!!!==================================

joints working in under version 1.8.0 [video](https://vimeo.com/88647429)

Hi,

In the older version >1.8.0 I used to spawn objects in the world and then connect them via dynamically created joints, however in later versions they act unnatural. I spawn the objects either from a plugin where I create an sdf from string and then insert it via World::InsertModelSDF(const sdf::SDF &_sdf) , I also tested it by including them from the .world file as a model.

I simplified the creation of the dynamic joints, took out all the physics parameters, and tried it in two ways, as a fixed joint and and a movable one (changing high and low stop).

void Plugin::CreateDynamicJoint(physics::LinkPtr _center_link, physics::LinkPtr _ext_link)

    joint->Attach(_center_link, _ext_link);

    joint->SetAxis(0, math::Vector3(0.0, 0.0, 1.0));

    joint->SetHighStop(0, 0);
    joint->SetLowStop(0, -0);
}

Here are some videos with how the models act after the joints are created ( I added some hardcoded visuals to it as well since dynamically created joints don't support visuals, see Issue #1077 , where, the green marked boxes are the _ext_links, and the blue marked box is the _center_link).

Videos with static joints ( high/low stop = 0 ):

Videos with movable joints ( high/low stop = ~ +/- 0.3 ):

In the videos the hand touches the boxes first, then it creates a fixed joint with it to lift it up, sometimes they explode only when touching, other times when moving or dropping them.

During the tests I switched between child and parent links, meaning in one case _ext_links were the children, all connecting to the _center_link parent, and vice versa when all _ext_links were parents, and the only child, _center_link, was connecting to them.

Which brings up another question, the only difference between child and parent links is that the pose and axis when creating them is relative to the child, but it has nothing to do with the idea that a child link should have only one parent, so it should work both ways?

Am I doing something wrong, or this is just some kind of weird bug?

I will try now to create an sdf string dynamically regarding the positions of the links, add the joints there, delete the model and then spawn it from the sdf string, see how that behaves, I will keep you posted when that is finished.

==========================UPDATE!!!==================================

So it seems the problem is not with loading an SDF or not, I created a plugin which deletes the model, and creates a new one in SDF string form, with joints between the links, here are two videos with it (when the boxes turn green/blue the model has been deleted and re-spawned as SDF with joints) :

center_parent

center_child

As a next step I outputed the SDF string into a file and loaded it from the world:

So it's obvious it has nothing to do with the way the joints are loaded, I am definitely doing something wrong, but I cannot figure it out what, maybe the joint axis counts, but that wouldn't be the case for fixed joints, plus the code worked for versions before 1.8.0.

Here are the sdf files of the working model (the pancake spheres), and the one that crashes (boxes).

working_model

NOT_working

values.title: DARTLink::SetTorque using wrong frame?

content.raw:
There is a new test that spawns models with different pose offsets and uses `Link::SetTorque` to apply a torque in the global frame. DART is currently failing this test.

See [PhysicsFrictionTest::LinkGetWorldInertia](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/eff6e66f57cc/test/integration/physics_friction.cc#cl-624) as of eff6e66f57cc.

See PhysicsFrictionTest::LinkGetWorldInertia as of eff6e66f57cc.

values.title: Add sdf generating functions for physics / sensors

content.raw:
There are multiple versions of sdf spawning functions in our testing suite 
([ServerFixture](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/bb512e8b7dcc77016370f47520b3183fdb9e27cf/test/ServerFixture.hh?at=default#cl-389),
[joint_test](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/bb512e8b7dcc77016370f47520b3183fdb9e27cf/test/integration/joint_test.hh?at=default#cl-135),
[physics_friction](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/bb512e8b7dcc77016370f47520b3183fdb9e27cf/test/integration/physics_friction.cc?at=default#cl-131)).
Some of these can be consolidated, but it occurred to me that it could be useful to put some of this functionality in the public API (create some simple classes that encapsulate the joint options, then output either sdf as a std::string, or spawn it and return a pointer).
content.html: There are multiple versions of sdf spawning functions in our testing suite (ServerFixture, joint_test, physics_friction). Some of these can be consolidated, but it occurred to me that it could be useful to put some of this functionality in the public API (create some simple classes that encapsulate the joint options, then output either sdf as a std::string, or spawn it and return a pointer).

values.title: fps view controller does not work in Gazebo 1.9.5

content.raw: <view_controller>fps</view_controller> worked correctly until I upgraded to Gazebo 1.9.5 (Ubuntu 12.04 LTS, ROS Hydro). Rotation with the left mouse button works, but forward-reverse translation with the scroll wheel now seems to move the camera along the world's x axis. Left-right translation with the right mouse button seems to move the camera along the world's y axis.

values.title: building from source error in under Ubuntu 12.04

content.raw:
see [question](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/5610/error-when-installing-from-source-on-ubuntu-1204/)

Hi,

I am getting a building error when installing from source under ubuntu 12.04.

The error:
~~~
gazebo-2.2.1/interfaces/player/player.h:22:38: fatal error: libplayercore/playercore.h: No such file or directory
~~~
the header file is located here:

/usr/include/player-3.0/libplayercore/playercore.h
Same error appears for older versions as well, such as 1.8.0.

The command `sudo apt-get remove libplayer*` did not fixed it for me, as in the following answer.

Also, under ubuntu 12.04 sudo apt-get install libogre-1.8-dev does not work, maybe the install tutorials should be updated?

values.title: Add api to freeze joint at current configuration

content.html:
This has been requested multiple times on gazebo answers. The function would set the high and low stops to the current joint position.

// Get the current joint position
gazebo::math::Angle currentPosition = joint->GetAngle(0);
joint->SetHighStop(0, currentPosition);
joint->SetLowStop(0, currentPosition);

values.title: Camera rotation different when attached to world or to intermediate link

content.raw:
Hi, 

 This bug seems different than #920 and I cannot see any fix related to the camera up to current version, so I guess my tests on ROS hydro + gazebo 1.9.3 should give the same result in latest versions.

The problem is simple. A camera (a kinect here) when rotated around 2 axis does not behave the same when linked with a fixed joint to world or to an intermediate fixed or moving link (tested on turtlebot also). 
The correct orientation of the image is obtained only when the camera is linked to world.

a test setup for ROS hydro is provided and should be started with (sorry for bad package name with capital letter)
roslaunch gazeboKinect kinect_empty_world_baselink.launch

a screen shot explains the result. 

best regards,
GuiHome

values.title: implement BulletLink::Set/GetKinematic
Problem setting simbody link kinematic/gravity/self-collide properties

content.raw:
discovered this while writing an integration test in `physics_msgs.cc` in pull request #1013

here is the output from the failing test

```
#!c++


/home/ian/depot/clones/gazebo6/test/integration/physics_msgs.cc:201: Failure
Value of: link->GetGravityMode()
  Actual: false
Expected: true
/home/ian/depot/clones/gazebo6/test/integration/physics_msgs.cc:230: Failure
Value of: newGravityMode != link->GetGravityMode()
  Actual: false
Expected: true
/home/ian/depot/clones/gazebo6/test/integration/physics_msgs.cc:270: Failure
Value of: link->GetKinematic() == newKinematicMode
  Actual: false
Expected: true
/home/ian/depot/clones/gazebo6/test/integration/physics_msgs.cc:301: Failure
Value of: link->GetSelfCollide() == newSelfCollideMode
  Actual: false
Expected: true
```

- default link gravity mode seems to be false when it should be true 

- setting link kinematic and self collide mode doesn't seem to have any effect
